articles.headline: U.S. to Include Home Care Aides in Wage and Overtime Law
articles.snippet: Almost two million home care workers will now be covered by the Fair Labor Standards Act, but the change will not go into effect until 2015.
articles.abstract: Almost two million home care workers will now be covered by the Fair Labor Standards Act, but the change will not go into effect until 2015.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration announced on Tuesday that it was extending minimum wage and overtime protections to the nation’s nearly two million home care workers.

articles.headline: Concern Over Drug Costs
articles.snippet: Many people worry that they will have to pay much more for their prescriptions, while some of the chronically ill fear they’ll have to pay thousands for their expensive drugs.
articles.abstract: Many people worry that they will have to pay much more for their prescriptions, while some of the chronically ill fear they’ll have to pay thousands for their expensive drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Among the most troubling questions facing consumers as they shop for insurance under the Obama administration’s new health care law is whether the plans will cover the drugs they take — and how much they will have to pay for them.

articles.headline: Lofty Bids Emerge for a Piece of New York’s Skyline
articles.snippet: Malkin Holdings may move ahead as early as this week with plans to sell shares to the public through a real estate investment trust.
articles.abstract: Malkin Holdings may move ahead as early as this week with plans to sell shares to the public through a real estate investment trust.
articles.lead_paragraph: After months of contentious behind-the-scenes battles, the public may finally get its chance to own a piece of a New York City landmark — the Empire State Building.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Charles V. Bagli

articles.headline: S.&P. Bond Deals Are on the Rise Since It Relaxed Rating Criteria
articles.snippet: As banks began reviving the market for bonds tied to home loans, S.& P.’s tough stance was hurting the bottom line.
articles.abstract: As banks began reviving the market for bonds tied to home loans, S.& P.’s tough stance was hurting the bottom line.
articles.lead_paragraph: During a meeting at Standard & Poor’s New York offices in the summer of 2012, analysts responsible for rating bonds tied to home loans were informed that their unit had sustained big losses in the previous quarter.

articles.headline: In Arrival of 2 iPhones, 3 Lessons
articles.snippet: Consider Apple’s two new iPhones, the 5C (budget model) and the 5S. Not exactly innovative, but they look good and the software is more efficient to navigate.
articles.abstract: Consider Apple’s two new iPhones, the 5C (budget model) and the 5S. Not exactly innovative, but they look good and the software is more efficient to navigate.
articles.lead_paragraph: We can draw three lessons from the arrival of Apple’s two new iPhone models, the 5C and 5S.

articles.headline: Extended Ruling by Secret Court Backs Collection of Phone Data
articles.snippet: The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court released a previously classified opinion in which it said the National Security Agency’s call-log program was constitutional and did not violate Americans’ privacy rights.
articles.abstract: The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court released a previously classified opinion in which it said the National Security Agency’s call-log program was constitutional and did not violate Americans’ privacy rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court on Tuesday offered its most extensive public explanation for why it has allowed the government to keep records of all Americans’ phone calls, releasing a previously classified  opinion in which it said the program was constitutional and did not violate Americans’ privacy rights.

articles.headline: U.N. Data on Gas Attack Point to Assad’s Top Forces
articles.snippet: Details buried in a United Nations report indicate the Syrian military launched the chemical attack from the same ridges it used for firing conventional munitions.
articles.abstract: Details buried in a United Nations report indicate the Syrian military launched the chemical attack from the same ridges it used for firing conventional munitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Details buried in the United Nations report on the Syrian chemical weapons attack point directly at elite military formations loyal to President Bashar al-Assad, some of the strongest findings to date that suggest the government gassed its own people.

articles.headline: Reaping Profit After Assisting on Health Law
articles.snippet: Those who had a hand in the passage of President Obama’s health care law are now finding lucrative work in the private sector, as businesses try to understand the complex measure or profit from it.
articles.abstract: Those who had a hand in the passage of President Obama’s health care law are now finding lucrative work in the private sector, as businesses try to understand the complex measure or profit from it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Washington’s health care revolving door is spinning fast as the new online health insurance marketplaces, a central provision of President Obama’s health care law, are set to open Oct. 1. Those who had a hand in the law’s passage are now finding lucrative work in the private sector, as businesses try to understand the complex measure, reshape it by pressing for regulatory changes — or profit from it.

articles.headline: A Magazine for Farm-to-Table
articles.snippet: Modern Farmer seeks to take advantage of a food movement that has fueled growth in farmer’s markets and community-supported agriculture.
articles.abstract: Modern Farmer seeks to take advantage of a food movement that has fueled growth in farmer’s markets and community-supported agriculture.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUDSON, N.Y. — When a fledgling magazine gets former President Bill Clinton to contribute an article, you would think he would be featured on the cover. But the cover model for the current issue of the quarterly Modern Farmer is a sleepy-looking goat. Mr. Clinton is mentioned between articles on outer space farming and soil cuisine.

articles.headline: Breathing Room for Emerging Markets Watching Money Flee
articles.snippet: While previous exoduses by investors from emerging markets have caused bank failures, bankruptcies and layoffs, the latest retrenchment has been much milder.
articles.abstract: While previous exoduses by investors from emerging markets have caused bank failures, bankruptcies and layoffs, the latest retrenchment has been much milder.
articles.lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — When the Asian financial crisis hit in 1997, sales plummeted 95 percent and stayed down for six months at the IGP Group, Indonesia’s dominant manufacturer of car and truck axles. Four-fifths of the company’s workers lost their jobs.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher, Simon Romero and Ceylan Yeginsu
